I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission for the People's Republic of China (PRC), 
the  Government  confirmed  its  request  for  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  help  formulate  and 
implement policy reform in road  transport.1 The Asian Development Bank (ADB)  Fact-Finding 
Mission visited the PRC in  September 2003 and  discussed road transport sector issues with 
officials of the central Government. This report is based on the understanding and agreement 
reached  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  costs,  terms  of  reference,  and 
implementation arrangements for the TA, and the Mission's observations in the field. The  TA 
framework, outlining the goal, purpose, outputs, and inputs, is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC’s economic development in the last decade has resulted in a rapid growth in 
transport  demand.  The  economy’s  changing  structure  and  increasing  diversification  have 
altered the pattern of transport demand. Between 1992 and 2002, the demand for road freight 
transport grew at 6.1% per annum, reaching 678 billion ton-kilometer (km), which was faster 
than the growth of the total freight market. Consequently, the share of road transport in total 
freight transport rose from 12.9% to 13.4%. The demand for road passenger transport also grew 
faster than the total passenger transport market at 9.4% per annum during the same period, 
reaching 781 billion passenger-km. The modal share of roads in the total passenger transport 
rose from 45.9%  in 1992  to 55.3% in 2002. The growth in  the demand for road transport 
resulted, in part, from deregulation in the road transport industry. The movement of goods and 
passengers will increasingly be by road, as road transport is more flexible and responsive to 
needs in a market economy than other modes. 
 
3.  In line with growth in transport demand, the vehicle fleet expanded rapidly. In 2002, the 
vehicle fleet totaled 20.5 million trucks, cars, buses, and other motorized vehicles (motorcycles 
and agricultural vehicles), three times the size of the 1992 fleet. The number of privately owned 
motor vehicles increased eight times during this period, from 1.2 million vehicles to 9.7 million. 
Trucks accounted for 35% of the total privately owned vehicles; cars and buses, 64%; and other 
specialized vehicles, 1%. Despite the rapid increase in the total number of vehicles, there were 
only 1.6 vehicles (truck, car, or bus) per 100 people. This figure is low relative to other countries in 
the Asia and Pacific region.2 Not until the early 1980s were modern vehicles imported and joint 
ventures formed with foreign automobile manufacturers to introduce modern technology. Given 
the PRC's rapid economic growth and low vehicle ownership, both the public and private vehicle 
fleets are expected to continue to grow rapidly in the coming years. This will result in substantial 
increases in the volume of road traffic, mounting congestion, and more vehicle emissions. The 
high share of slow-moving traffic, mainly tractors, bicycles, and nonmotorized agricultural vehicles, 
aggravates road congestion, and is a major cause of traffic accidents. 
 
4.  Private sector participation and owner-operator businesses have grown rapidly in the 
road transport industry. This has improved the level of service and increased competition, thus 
ensuring that some of the savings in vehicle operating costs resulting from better roads are 
passed on to customers. In 2001, there were 558,000 passenger transport operators with 1.4 
million vehicles and 16.9 million passenger seats. Of these, 561,000 vehicles (41%) with 5.5 
million passenger seats (32%) belonged to individual operators. There were 4.1 million freight

transport operators with 4.6 million vehicles and a capacity of 15.7 million tons. Of these, 2.3 
million vehicles (or 51%) with a capacity  of 6.6 million tons (42%) belonged to individual 
operators. Only a small number of large operators are in the road transport. While the number of 
good quality buses and passenger seats increased annually at 14.2% and 23.8%, respectively, 
between 1996 and 2001, these premium services still accounted for a small share of the total. 
The transport capacity in rural areas and level of service are low. Improvements are needed to 
meet the transport demand. Energy efficient large trucks accounted for only 38.1% of the fleet 
while small trucks accounted for 51.1%. Structural adjustments in vehicle size and type are 
needed to improve the quality and efficiency of the road transport industry and to improve fuel 
efficiency of the fleet. 
 
5.  The Government is aware of the  broad issues affecting road transport and plans to 
increase the operating efficiency of the industry to  increase the overall capacity to transport 
freight and passengers. This will help to satisfy the growing demand and complement the capital 
investment in road construction. Some reform initiatives have been implemented. The trucking 
industry has been deregulated and market entry has become easier. A system of national 
permits  has  been  developed  for  interprovincial  trucking  companies.  Freight  tariffs  are 
determined by the market, and privately owned freight operators account for 74% of the industry. 
Passenger fares are still regulated by provincial governments, and public bus companies are 
largely owned by provincial communications departments. 
 
6.  Despite this progress, the operating efficiency of the road transport industry is low, partly 
because the policy and regulatory framework is not yet suitable for a market economy. Also 
operations, management, and maintenance practices of road transport operators need to be 
improved. A policy and regulatory environment conducive to improving the provision of transport 
services needs to be created. Laws and regulations need to be modified to open up the road 
transport  market  to  foreign  operators  in  line  with  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO) 
accession agreement. The current administrative system for examining and approving operators 
needs  to  be  reformed  to  foster  development  of  the  road  transport  industry.  Structural 
adjustments in road transport are needed in the following areas: (i) organizational restructuring 
to  make  the  road  transport  enterprises  more  commercially  viable; (ii)  improving  the  low 
technology,  unreliable,  and  uncomfortable  vehicles  to  meet  technical  standards  in  safety, 
environmental impact, fuel efficiency, and capacity; and (iii) developing new services such as 
freight forwarding and automobile maintenance to meet the changing transport demand. A more 
transparent  and  open  market  for  road  transport  and  automobile  maintenance  must  be 
established by addressing problems of traffic safety and service quality caused by illegal 
operations  and  maintenance,  local  monopolies,  and  overloading  of  trucks.  Finally,  road 
transport laws and regulations need to be enforced more effectively. To do so requires raising 
the awareness and skill base of traffic enforcement officers. 
 
7.  The impact of the PRC’s WTO accession agreement to open the transport market to 
foreign companies needs to be analyzed. In the road transport sector, this requirement applies 
to transport operation services, maintenance and repair services, and storage and warehousing 
services. Prior to the effectivity of these commitments in 2001, foreign investment was not 
allowed to exceed 49% in joint ventures in these  areas. Within  1 year of effectivity (2002), 
foreign majority ownership was allowed, and by 2004, wholly foreign-owned subsidiaries will be 
allowed. Under the terms of the PRC’s WTO accession,  cooperative businesses and wholly 
foreign-owned enterprises enjoy equal treatment with domestic companies. An ADB-financed

3
TA3 recommended opening the transport and logistical business to foreign investment and 
allowing greater competition.  In November 2001, the Government issued the  “Provisions on 
Foreign Investment in the PRC’s Road Transport” regulation, which was designed to streamline 
approval procedures for foreign investments, define the scope for foreign investments, and 
clarify issues regarding post-investment changes. By the end of 2001, foreign investment had 
been made in 820 passenger service, freight service, and logistics and maintenance service 
companies mostly in coastal areas, such as Shanghai, Jiangsu, and Guangdong. Despite these 
achievements, there remain many challenges, including a lack of transparency and inadequate 
enforcement  of  regulations  so  that  foreign  companies  can  fully  take  advantage  of  the 
opportunities offered by the PRC’s WTO accession. 
 
8.  ADB's operating strategy4 in the PRC’s road sector is designed to remove infrastructure 
constraints and support policy and institutional reforms. Since 1991, ADB has provided 27 loans 
totaling $4.8 billion to help finance 3,555 km of highway development and improvement of an 
associated  local  road  network.  ADB  road  projects  are  generally  being  implemented 
satisfactorily.  ADB  has  provided  21  advisory  TAs  totaling  $12.9  million  to  support  the 
development  of  road  infrastructure  by  addressing  policy  and  institutional  issues,  including 
highway  planning,  road  safety,  human  resource  development,  transport  pricing, 
commercialization  and  corporatization  of  enterprises,  and  mobilization  of  nongovernment 
financial  resources,  and  to  analyze  the  impact  of  better  roads  in  social  development 
improvements. ADB  provided a TA5 in 1993 to help identify ways of  raising road transport 
efficiency by improving the utilization of resources; increasing the market orientation of the 
industry; eliminating barriers to increased private sector participation, including foreign direct 
investment; and removing regulatory and institutional constraints on efficient operation. While 
the TA achieved the envisaged objectives to a certain degree, its impact was constrained due to 
the limited responsibility of the selected executing agency and a lack of internal coordination 
within the concerned government agency.6 As a result, the TA was rated partially successful. 
Because of these lessons learned of experience, the executing agency for this TA was carefully 
selected and the importance of coordination among relevant departments was discussed during 
fact-finding. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The purpose of the TA is to help the Government improve the performance of the road 
transport industry by formulating and implementing policy reforms in  the road freight and 
passenger industries. The main output of the TA will be a realistic road transport reform action 
plan and assistance in implementing the action plan.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  To  achieve  the  purpose  and  deliver  outputs,  the  TA  will (i) review the policy and 
regulatory  framework  in  the  road  transport  industry;  (ii)  examine  the  factors  affecting  the

analysis in selected provinces, involving provincial  governments,  transport  operators (both 
domestic and foreign), transport users, nongovernment organizations, and other interested 
parties; and (iv) review lessons learned from other countries based on their experience. Key 
activities  include  reviewing  relevant  reports  and  documents,  stakeholder  discussions, 
conducting  field  surveys  in  selected  provinces,  and  training  and  seminars  to  disseminate 
findings of the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $630,000 equivalent, consisting of $324,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $306,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  costs.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange costs and 
$176,000 equivalent of local currency costs. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
TA  funding  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  balance  of  the  local  currency  cost, 
equivalent to  $130,000, through the provision of  counterpart staff, office facilities, and other 
support services. Detailed cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The Ministry of Communications (MOC)  will be the Executing Agency, and will appoint 
suitable counterpart staff who will be responsible for supervising and coordinating the TA 
activities on a day-to-day basis, including monitoring progress; assisting in resolving issues that 
may  arise  during  TA  implementation;  assisting  in  arranging  meetings;  and  liaising  with 
Government agencies concerned, including the Ministry of Finance, the National Development 
and Reform Commission, and the Ministry of Public Security. Policy guidance to the consultants 
will be provided by MOC and other ministries, as appropriate, which will meet to discuss the 
consultant’s report at the inception, interim, and draft final stages. The consultants are expected 
to be fielded in September 2004, and their work will be carried out over about 6 months with 
completion in March 2005.  Limited office equipment will be procured under the consultants 
contract  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement,  and  ownership  will  be 
transferred to the Government after TA completion. The consultants will maintain close contact 
with MOC and inform them of the progress of their work and findings.  Workshops involving 
MOC and other government offices, ADB, and the consultants will be held in the PRC to review 
the findings of the consultants, and the main findings will be disseminated through publication. A 
draft outline of the final report is in Appendix 3. 
 
13.  A team of international consulting firms in association with domestic consultants will be 
selected and engaged by ADB using the simplified technical proposal procedures based on the 
quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic 
consultants. The TA will require 10 person-months of international and  18 person-months of 
domestic consulting services to carry out  the study. The international consultants will have 
expertise in the following fields: (i) transport policy and regulation, (ii) road passenger transport, 
and (iii) road freight transport. The international consultants will be encouraged to use domestic 
consultants, who will have expterise in (i) transport policy and regulations, (ii) transport economics, 
(iii) road passenger transport, and (iv) road freight transport. The outline terms of reference for the 
TA are at Appendix 4.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Policy Reform in Road Transport, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  Review existing reports on the road transport industry in the People’s Republic of China 
to  examine  the  progress  of  reform  in  the  industry.  In  particular,  examine  the  status  of 
implementation of the relevant recommendations made under an  Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  improving  efficiency  in  the  road  transport1 and other 
relevant reports2 including a broad study on transport sector reform being carried out by the 
Ministry of Communications (MOC).  
 
B.  Road Transport Policy and Regulation 
2.  The consultant will do the following: (i) Review the road transport policies affecting both 
freight and passenger transport in the context of broader policies concerning road infrastructure 
and other transport modes, including the multimodal transport of containers. (ii) Define the 
overall objectives and responsibilities for policy-making and implementation,  the roles of the 
government and private sector in road transport, and the basis for road transport regulations to 
promote efficient use of roads  and vehicle fleets  and to promote  safety and  environmental 
protection.  The  policy  framework  should  endorse  the  primary  role  of  market  forces  in 
determining price and service levels with the role of the  Government limited to ensuring that 
competitive conditions prevail and that safety and environmental considerations are met. 
 
3.  The consultant will assess the regulatory framework to identify  aspects that are not 
consistent with the regulatory objectives and to define the need for alternative regulations. The 
scope of regulations should cover (i) definition of the road transport system, (ii) goals and 
objectives of the regulations, (iii) role of the various levels of government, (iv) scope of the road 
transport  development  tasks  and  the  role  of  central  and  local  regulatory  agencies,  (v) 
development of effective trucking and heavy vehicle industry, and (vi) coordination between the 
concerned  government  ministries  and  departments.  The  provision  of  subsidies  and  cargo 
insurance, and market entry conditions and national treatment of foreign-owned passenger and 
freight companies will also be reviewed. 
 
4.  The review of the regulatory framework will emphasize the following three areas, among 
others: (i) road traffic; (ii) vehicle, including off-road (farm) vehicles, and driver licensing; and (iii) 
road transport licensing and management. For the road traffic, review the following aspects: 
administrative responsibilities; general rules of behavior; status of signs and signals; rules for 
proper movement of traffic; speed limits; responsibility of motor vehicle operators; rights and 
duties of pedestrians; special rules for cyclists and motor cyclists; proper use of motor vehicle 
equipment, road signs, signals, and markings; authorities to investigate traffic violations  and 
traffic accidents, traffic accident reporting and information system; penalty provisions; and use 
of  seat  belts  and  the  desirability  of  the  use  of  car  seats  for  infants.  Regulatory  issues 
surrounding nonmotorized transport will also be reviewed.

5.  For vehicle and driver licensing, assess the following aspects: vehicle equipment and 
registration, vehicle sizes (including over-dimension vehicles), weights and proper equipping of 
seat belts, and driver licensing. For road transport operator licensing, review administration of 
operator  licenses;  refusal,  suspension  and  revocation  of  licenses;  license  fees;  appeal 
procedures; planning of routes and terminals;  control  of  terminals; monitoring of services; 
reporting of offences; enforcement of license regulations; penalty provisions; and the system to 
monitor the payment of fines. The possibility of providing bus stops on the expressways (main 
lane,  rest  areas,  and  interchanges)  will  be  examined  and  changes  to  the  regulations 
recommended, if needed. 
 
6.  Review the regulatory changes3 since December 2001 in line with commitments in the 
World Trade Organization  (WTO) accession agreement  to open the  freight and passenger 
markets to foreign investment in road transport, vehicle maintenance and repairing services, 
and transport-related services such as storage and warehousing. 
 
7.  Review the institutional framework and capacity for formulating and implementing the 
policy and regulations at the central and local government levels. 
 
C.  Road Transport Operations 
8.  The consultant will analyze the structure and operational performance of the freight and 
passenger transport industries with due consideration to types of ownership, size of companies, 
types of license (grades I to V), vehicle fleet, types and quality of services offered, load factors, 
vehicle utilization, financial positions, expressway toll rates, vehicle emissions, safety features, 
and accident costs. 
 
9.  To identify the factors affecting operating costs and level of service in the trucking 
industry, examine the operating costs (variable costs and fixed costs) incurred under each item 
in relation to prevailing input prices. Analyze the operating cost per ton-kilometer (km), fuel 
consumption, and the number of staff per truck. 
 
10.  Measure the relevant performance indicators in relation to those expected for efficient 
operations based on best international practice. Vehicle use (vehicle-kilometer per year) may be 
affected by road conditions due to inadequate maintenance,  use of  obsolete or technically 
inferior vehicles, poor driving behavior and maintenance, and operating practices or regulatory 
constraints, which limit operating hours. Vehicle use may also be affected by restrictions on 
working  hours  (for  example  due  to  regulations  or  safety  reasons),  seasonal  variations  in 
demand, vehicle availability, average loads, and level of service. 
 
11.  Analyze problems affecting performance and their effects. In addition to the factors listed 
in para. 10, examine the following: (i) the average ratio of trucks per operator, indicating the 
ownership structure of the industry; (ii) the proportion of traffic carried by own-account trucking, 
indicating important characteristics of the industry and the way it might be regulated; (iii) the 
extent of specialization in trucking, indicating the level of development in transport businesses 
and services; (iv) logistics systems; and (v) provision of cargo insurance.

12.  Examine the cost breakdown of bus services in a similar way as for the trucking industry. 
In  doing  so,  take  into  account  the  possibility  of  fare  subsidy  and  cross-subsidies  among 
operating routes. 
 
13.  Measure the relevant performance indicators compared to best international practices 
for efficient operation. Vehicle utilization (bus-kilometer per year) may be affected by road 
conditions, which may limit speeds; unreliable buses, which often break down; and lack of 
efficient  scheduling.  The  level  of  service  of  bus  operation  may  be  expressed  as  follows: 
passenger travel times, predictability of departure and arrival times, the rate of bus breakdowns, 
availability of special features (comfortable chairs, air conditioning, toilets, etc), and passenger 
facilities at bus stations. 
 
14.  Analyze problems affecting bus performance and their effects. In addition to the factors 
listed in para. 13, examine the following: (i) travel patterns, (ii) lack of timetables for bus services, 
(iii) lack of passenger choice over type of service and operators, (iv) lack of private sector bus 
operators on route services, and (v) lack of bus stations along the expressways. 
 
15.  Review the actual and expected impact of the WTO accession on the structure and 
performance of the road transport industry. Review the need to establish a mechanism to 
facilitate public and private consultation at national and provincial levels to promote private 
sector participation in the road transport. 
 
16.  To investigate the regulations and cost and quality of road transport services (including 
freight forwarders, booking agents, and insurance companies in case of freight service), carry 
out a stakeholder analysis in two or three provincial level case studies. The case studies will 
cover both domestic and foreign operations. The provinces will be selected in consultation with 
MOC and ADB. Preference will be given to selecting provinces in which ADB has significant 
road sector operations. 
 
17.  The following type of surveys will be carried out under the case studies: (i) roadside 
counts and interviews to obtain  information about characteristics of supply and demand; (ii) 
interviews of transport operators, consignors, and freight forwarders to find out customer level of 
service and charges; (iii) analysis of operating records showing revenue and expenditure with 
supporting  statistics  like  vehicle-kilometer  operated  and  fuel  consumed;  (iv)  interviews  of 
informal operators in operational centers to identity important issues and concerns of transport 
operators; and (v) analysis of records of transport data to analyze changes in the industry and to 
identify traffic trends and possible effects of past regulatory changes. 
 
18.  Develop a set of performance indicators to measure the efficiency of the road transport 
industry, and define the baseline and targets with a timeframe. 
 
D.  Road Transport Policy Reform Action Plan 
19.  Based on the foregoing, identify the policy and regulatory framework, and ownership and 
operating characteristics that constrain the performance of the road transport industry, and 
propose improvements to increase operating efficiency, including private participation in the 
industry. A set of proposed actions as agreed with MOC will be included in the road transport 
policy  reform  action  plan,  indicating  the  current  situation,  proposed  actions,  performance 
indicators (baseline and targets) with a time frame, and responsible agency.

Appendix 4  13
20.  Review lessons learned from other countries in policy and regulations, and industrial 
structure and performance. Such countries may include Australia, India, and the United States, 
subject to confirmation by  MOC. As part of this  exercise, prepare an overseas training for 
government officials concerned. The training program and a list of participants will require ADB 
approval. 
 
21.  Organize two workshops to discuss among various stakeholders the findings of the 
provincial level case studies, and disseminate the outcome of the work at the time of the draft 
final report. A final report will be edited for publication (bilingual) and a broad based information 
dissemination strategy will be developed. 
 
E.  Reporting Requirements 
22.  The consultants will submit the following reports:  (i) an inception report 4 weeks after 
commencement of services; (ii) an interim report after 10 weeks, (iii) a draft final report after 17 
weeks; and (iii) a final report after 24 weeks. MOC requires five copies of each report in English 
and Chinese while the following Government  offices need two copies of each report in the 
English and Chinese languages: Ministry of Finance (TA Division), National Development and 
Reform Commission, and Ministry of Public Security. ADB requires five copies of each report in 
English. The final report will be edited for publication (bilingual). All reports will be submitted in 
both hard copy and soft copy.
